description: From Middle English pursevant et al., from Old French pursuivant, present participle of pursuivre (“to follow”). Doublet of pursuant.

entries.meaning: (heraldry) A functionary of lower rank than a herald, but discharging similar duties; called also pursuivant at arms; an attendant of the heralds, e.g. in the College of Arms.
examples: The herald Hope, forerunning Fear, / And Fear, the pursuivant of Hope.

entries.meaning: (Freemasonry) A Grand Lodge Officer who guards the inner door during a meeting of the Grand Lodge
A royal messenger, (particularly) one with the authority to execute warrants.
(law enforcement, by extension) A warrant officer.
